\#\#\# User: How to reverse the cooridnates order of this MultiPoint:

```
MULTIPOINT (92 169, 100 163.552380952381, 105.2167832167832 160, 266.7552447552447 50, 290 34.17142857142857, 302 26)

```

to this:

```
 MULTIPOINT (302 26, 290 34.17142857142857, 266.7552447552447 50,  105.2167832167832 160, 100 163.552380952381, 92 169)

```

I tried this and getting an error:

```
intPoints.coords[::-1])

```

> > > NotImplementedError: Multi\-part geometries do not provide a coordinate sequence

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'm not sure why the order matters to you but the [shapely manual](https://shapely.readthedocs.io/en/stable/manual.html#collections-of-points) shows wrapping the `MultiPoint` in a `list`:

```
pprint.pprint(list(points.geoms))

```

so I would expect something like:

```
points = MultiPoint(list(points.geoms)[::-1]) 

```

to work. Though the manual makes no claims that `MultiPoints` honour the order of the input list.

0.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: When working with a MultiPoint geometry in Shapely, which of the following approaches is most likely to successfully reverse the order of coordinates?

A) Use the slice notation directly on the MultiPoint object:
   reversed_points = multipoint[::-1]

B) Access the coords attribute and reverse it:
   reversed_points = MultiPoint(multipoint.coords[::-1])

C) Convert the MultiPoint to a list of its geometries, reverse the list, and create a new MultiPoint:
   reversed_points = MultiPoint(list(multipoint.geoms)[::-1])

D) Use the reverse() method on the MultiPoint object:
   multipoint.reverse()
   reversed_points = multipoint

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
A) This approach is incorrect because MultiPoint objects don't support direct slicing.
B) This fails because MultiPoint geometries don't provide a coordinate sequence through the coords attribute.
C) This is the correct approach. It converts the MultiPoint to a list of its component geometries, reverses that list, and creates a new MultiPoint from the reversed list.
D) MultiPoint objects don't have a reverse() method, so this approach would result in an error.

The correct method (C) is based on the Shapely documentation and the suggested solution in the StackExchange answer. It's important to note that while this method will reverse the order of the points, the Shapely documentation doesn't guarantee that MultiPoints will maintain the order of the input list in all operations.

documentation.text: \#\#\# User: My question is a like the one here: [only with different symbol](https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/196312/command-o-is-invalid-in-mathmode). With typing: `\[\^{\i}\]` i want to get a get a **i** with a **^** (replacing the dot) on its head. So far, so good. Means it works (i get the symbol i wish to get) but TeXstudio (Version 2\.12\.10 (git 2\.12\.10\)) gives me two warnings also: > Command \\^ invalid in math mode and > Command \\i invalid in math mode The command `\hat{i}` gives me an **i** with a **^** ontop. That is not excactly what i want. The solution with `$\o$` replaced by `\varnothing or \Emptyset` seams to be the same, well maybe i'm just searching for the right word for my symbol in question? Any suggestions? --- **Update 1** after getting a solution form @Henri Menke (On the left side of the equation) The left one is the result of `\hat{\imath}` result, `\cdot`, the right one it the result of `\^{\i}` [![The left one is the result of \hat{\imath}, the right one is the result of \^{\i}](https://i.stack.imgur.com/56DEg.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/56DEg.png) With other words: [![Not the same: The left one is the result of \hat{\imath}, the right one is the result of \^{\i}](https://i.stack.imgur.com/KwF0b.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/KwF0b.png) Lets assume that `\hat{\imath}` is indeed the right symbol, than i have to write `\(\hat{\imath}\)` (with math enviroment) every time i need to use it in my text for reference? --- **Update 2** I knew that link before asking my question but it wasn't helpfull in my case. Maybe have a look [here, for looking up other unknown symbols](https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/14/how-to-look-up-a-symbol-or-identify-a-math-symbol-or-character) if you have a "similar" question (Please credit him if it helps you) \- \#\#\# Top Answer: You can access the dotless version of i and j in math mode using `\imath` and `\jmath`. ``` \documentclass{article} \begin{document} $\hat{\imath}$ $\hat{\jmath}$ \end{document} ``` [![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/lqQlL.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/lqQlL.png)

\#\#\# User: Let $V$ be a real inner product space. If $W\=V\\times V$ with the operations
$(u\_1,v\_1\)\+(u\_2,v\_2\)\=(u\_1\+u\_2,v\_1\+v\_2\)$ and $(\\alpha \+i\\beta)(u,v)\=(\\alpha u\-\\beta v,\\alpha v\+\\beta u)$, where $u, u\_1,u\_2,v,v\_1,v\_2\\in V$ and $\\alpha,\\beta$ are scalars. 

> Show that $W$ is a complex inner product with the inner product
>  $$\\langle (u\_1,v\_1\),(u\_2,v\_2\)\\rangle\=\\langle u\_1,u\_2\\rangle\+\\langle v\_1,v\_2\\rangle\+i\\langle v\_1,u\_2\\rangle\-i\\langle u\_1,v\_2\\rangle$$

I do not know how to connect these operations, plz help

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: A $\\bf{\\text{real inner product}}$ on $V$ is defined as a binary map $\\langle\\cdot, \\cdot\\rangle:V\\times V\\to \\mathbb{C}$ with the properties:

1\) $\\langle u, u\\rangle \\geq 0$ for all $u\\in V$ with equality only if $u \= 0$

2\) $\\langle u, v\\rangle \= \\langle v, u\\rangle$ for all $u,v\\in V$

3\) $\\langle k u,v\\rangle \= k \\langle u,v\\rangle$ for all $k\\in\\mathbb{R}, u,v\\in V$.

As a consequence of 2 and 3, a real inner product is also linear in its second coordinate.

---

A $\\bf{\\text{complex inner product}}$ on $W$ is defined as a binary map $\\langle\\cdot, \\cdot\\rangle:W\\times W\\to \\mathbb{C}$ with the properties:

1\) $\\langle x, x\\rangle \\geq 0$ for all $x\\in W$ with equality only if $x \= 0$

2\) $\\langle x, y\\rangle \= \\overline{\\langle y, x\\rangle}$ for all $x,y\\in W$

3\) $\\langle \\alpha x,y\\rangle \= \\alpha \\langle x,y\\rangle$ for all $\\alpha\\in\\mathbb{C}, x,y\\in W$.

As a consequence of 2 and 3, a complex inner product is conjugate\-linear in its second coordinate.

---

Denote the bilinear map given in the question by $\\langle \\cdot, \\cdot \\rangle\_{W}$, and denote the real inner products on $V$ by $\\langle \\cdot, \\cdot \\rangle$. It is important to distinguish between these two. The idea behind this problem is to $\\bf{\\text{use}}$ the fact that $\\langle \\cdot, \\cdot \\rangle$ is a real inner product to $\\bf{\\text{prove}}$ that $\\langle \\cdot, \\cdot\\rangle\_{W}$ is a complex inner product.

Let's check that the first property is satisfied. Let $x \= (u,v)\\in W$, so that $u,v\\in V$.

\\begin{eqnarray\*}
\\langle x, x\\rangle\_{W} \&\=\& \\langle u, u \\rangle \+ 
\\langle v, v \\rangle \+ i\\langle v, u \\rangle \- i\\langle u, v \\rangle\\\\
\&\=\& \\langle u, u \\rangle \+ 
\\langle v, v \\rangle \+ i\\langle u, v \\rangle \- i\\langle u, v \\rangle\\\\
\&\=\& \\langle u, u \\rangle \+ \\langle v, v\\rangle\\\\
\&\\geq\& 0
\\end{eqnarray\*}
and the only way we can get equality is if $u \= 0$ and $v \= 0$. In this case we have $x \= (0,0\)$, which establishes the first property.

The other two properties can be similarly verified.

2.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: In a complex inner product space W = V × V, where V is a real inner product space, which of the following statements is true about the complex inner product defined as 
⟨(u₁,v₁),(u₂,v₂)⟩ = ⟨u₁,u₂⟩ + ⟨v₁,v₂⟩ + i⟨v₁,u₂⟩ - i⟨u₁,v₂⟩?

A) The inner product is always real-valued for any two vectors in W.

B) The inner product satisfies ⟨αx,y⟩ = α⟨x,y⟩ for all α ∈ ℂ and x,y ∈ W, but is not necessarily conjugate-linear in its second argument.

C) The inner product is positive definite, conjugate symmetric, and linear in its first argument and conjugate-linear in its second argument.

D) The inner product satisfies all properties of a complex inner product except for conjugate symmetry.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
The given inner product satisfies all the properties of a complex inner product:

1. Positive definiteness: As shown in the derivation, ⟨x,x⟩ ≥ 0 for all x ∈ W, with equality only when x = (0,0).

2. Conjugate symmetry: It can be verified that ⟨x,y⟩ = ⟨y,x⟩̄ for all x,y ∈ W.

3. Linearity in the first argument and conjugate-linearity in the second: This follows from the properties of the real inner product on V and the definition of scalar multiplication in W.

Option A is incorrect because the inner product can be complex-valued. 
Option B is incorrect because the inner product is conjugate-linear in its second argument. 
Option D is incorrect because the inner product does satisfy conjugate symmetry.

Therefore, C is the correct answer, as it accurately describes all the properties of this complex inner product.

\#\#\# User: On my Windows 10, x64 with nVidia GTX 760 I am experiencing annoying effects: 

Every time my two screens are turned off to save energy or the OS goes into stand by mode causes all my windows to be moved to primary screen after waking up/ turning on the screens.
I set the screen\-off time to one minute. Moved firefox to screen 2, waited a minuted, moved my mouse to power on the screens \-\> firefox and everything else is back at primary screen.

I've uninstalled nvidia drivers completely, restarted and then installed them again but it looks like this wasn't it.

Is there something fancy, that can be done in that situation? I know this is not the default behaviour as I've had several 2\-screen set\-ups in my life and none showed this behaviour.

Screen 1 is connected via HDMI and Screen 2 via DVI\-D.
I cannot switch the connections as Screen 2 has no HDMI or Display Port.
But AFAIK DVI or HDMI shouldn't really matter

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I have tried numerous fixes which are in answers to similar questions on various forums, and none has really fixed the problem. Apparently, Microsoft initiates restoration of each window as soon as the logon prompt is displayed, and checks to see that the screen real estate is there as it does so. When it wakes the monitors, there can be a delay before a monitor is detected by the OS, and Windows uses a default simulated monitor if there is no monitor detected yet. Microsoft likes this behavior, as it prevents loss of access to offscreen windows if you reduce the number of screens, especially after someone disconnects a projector from a laptop at the end of a meeting. 

This delay in the monitor becoming visible to the system could also depend on how the monitor is attached to the system (VGA, HDMI, DVI or DisplayPort), and how the graphics adapter reports the monitor configuration during wake\-up. With my setup (Radeon R9 260, LG monitors, primary on PowerPort, older, smaller one on HDMI) it seems like the monitor configuration isn't fully visible to Windows until the little monitor health windows both go away.

I have found that I can avoid most moving and resizing if I am patient and careful about how I wake the system. 

The problem seems to be that pressing a key or mouse button initiates both wake and logon in a single action. Even while logon initiation is waiting for you to enter a password or select a different user, it starts waking up the windows from the previous session to save time. Therefor it can be looking at the monitor configuration to make sure the window placement is valid before many monitors wake and become ready and visible to the system. 

The trick is to separate wake from login initiation. One way is to use the computer power button to wake, assuming it is set to do that. One of my keyboards has a wake/sleep button, and that also works. 

The way that I generally use is to move the mouse (an arrow key would also work) to start to wake the system up, and then wait for the monitor to fully wake before pressing any other key or the mouse button to get the logon prompt. My monitors display a little window of configuration info at startup, and if I wait until both of those have disappeared before I press a key or mouse button to get the login prompt, the windows generally come up where they belong. I wait to see the background wallpaper up without a login prompt until the monitor initiation is complete, and then click to bring up the logon prompt.

If I start by pressing the mouse button or any of the other keyboard keys, or if that has happened since the computer went to sleep even if I never logged on, it seems to initiate both wake and logon (displaying the default user and accepting the password) at the same time. This causes the system to start waking up windows, program by program, without being able to see the monitors, and they all end up in the top left of my primary monitor. Sometimes, say if I move the mouse but then press the button too fast, some programs (say, Excel and Bing) have their windows moved there, and others (Chrome and Word, maybe) have them still where they were. I think that tends to confirm my theories above of why this works.

There is also a tendency of some windows to migrate down and right a bit on wakeup; I don't see much of a solution to that except to extend the window to the bottom or right edge of the screen, or at least to near it (hitting the bottom in Win10 tends to extend the window vertically over both screens, in a top/bottom configuration).

3.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: What is the primary reason for windows moving to the primary screen after waking up from sleep mode in a multi-monitor setup, according to the StackExchange answer?

A) The graphics card drivers are outdated or corrupted
B) Windows intentionally moves windows to prevent loss of access to offscreen content
C) The monitor connection type (HDMI, DVI, etc.) causes incompatibility issues
D) The user is not patient enough when waking up the system

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The answer explains that Microsoft initiates restoration of each window as soon as the logon prompt is displayed. If there's a delay in detecting all monitors, Windows uses a default simulated monitor, which can cause windows to move to the primary screen. This behavior is intentional to prevent loss of access to offscreen windows if the number of screens is reduced, such as when disconnecting a projector from a laptop after a meeting.

Option A is incorrect because the answer mentions that reinstalling drivers did not solve the issue. Option C is not the primary reason, although connection types can affect the speed at which monitors are detected. Option D, while patience is mentioned as a workaround, is not the root cause of the problem.

\#\#\# User: I have to show that $\\lim \\limits\_{n\\rightarrow\\infty}\\frac{n!}{(2n)!}\=0$ 

---

I am not sure if correct but i did it like this :
$(2n)!\=(2n)\\cdot(2n\-1\)\\cdot(2n\-2\)\\cdot ...\\cdot(2n\-(n\-1\))\\cdot (n!)$ so I have $$\\displaystyle \\frac{1}{(2n)\\cdot(2n\-1\)\\cdot(2n\-2\)\\cdot ...\\cdot(2n\-(n\-1\))}$$ and $$\\lim \\limits\_{n\\rightarrow \\infty}\\frac{1}{(2n)\\cdot(2n\-1\)\\cdot(2n\-2\)\\cdot ...\\cdot(2n\-(n\-1\))}\=0$$ is this correct ? If not why ?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It's correct, but I imagine you're expected to show a bit more work to *justify* your assertion that
$$\\lim \\limits\_{n\\rightarrow \\infty}\\frac{1}{(2n)\\cdot(2n\-1\)\\cdot(2n\-2\)\\cdot ...\\cdot(2n\-(n\-1\))}\=0$$
An easy way to do this is to bound this sequence of fractions with another, simpler one whose limit you know is 0\.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: To prove that lim_(n→∞) (n!)/(2n)! = 0, which of the following approaches is most rigorous and complete?

A) Simply state that (2n)! = (2n)(2n-1)(2n-2)...(n+1)(n!) and conclude that the limit of 1/[(2n)(2n-1)(2n-2)...(n+1)] must be 0 as n approaches infinity.

B) Use Stirling's approximation for factorials to rewrite the expression in terms of powers and exponentials, then evaluate the limit.

C) Bound the fraction by a simpler sequence known to converge to 0, such as (1/2)^n, and use the squeeze theorem to prove the limit.

D) Apply L'Hôpital's rule repeatedly until the limit can be easily evaluated.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
Option A lacks rigorous justification for why the limit is 0. 
Option B is valid but may be more complex than necessary. 
Option C is the most appropriate as it provides a rigorous proof using a simpler known limit, aligning with the suggestion in the documentation. 
Option D is incorrect as L'Hôpital's rule is not applicable to sequences.

The correct approach (C) involves bounding the sequence with a simpler one that converges to 0, which allows for a straightforward proof using the squeeze theorem. This method is both rigorous and relatively simple, making it the best choice for this problem.

\#\#\# User: So I was browsing stackoverflow and came across a question that sounded pretty interesting. I clicked through and the quality of the question was pretty poor. I immediately set out to giving it better tags, removing salutations, formatting code, and giving it a more descriptive title. 

After doing that and pushing submit, I realized that this question was posted in 2009 by some anonymous user. 

Is it OK to edit questions like this or not? If it's not OK, should there be some kind of warning when editing very old questions? 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you feel the question merits interest, in that it drew your attention, then it's inherently a worthwhile question (if only to you and the person who initially asked it). As it's a worthwhile question it's also deserving of care and attention.

The age of the question might may, potentially, make the subject\-matter somewhat historical (an older version of an IDE, reference to a now low\-use browser), and, of course, the original poster may no longer use the site (though you can tell that from the greyed\-out avatar on the question itself), so there may be no 'accept' points rewarded for providing an answer, however the edits will promote the question, and there may yet be up\-votes to reward the answerers.

It's worth remembering that that while editing might raise awareness of the question, it might also prompt others to close the question (the criteria for a 'good question' have changed over the years from 2009 to 2013\). This does *not*, however, reflect badly on your edits (any help you can give a question is worthwhile to my mind), but on the nature of the question itself.

The correct answer aligns with the overall message of the response, which encourages improving questions that are deemed interesting or worthwhile, regardless of when they were originally posted.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a Magento payment method model, what is the significance of setting the protected property $_isInitializeNeeded to true, and how does it affect the order state during the payment process?

A) It enables the initialize() method of the payment method, but has no effect on the order state.
B) It forces the order state to always be Order::STATE_PROCESSING, regardless of configuration.
C) It allows the payment method to determine the order state and status through the initialize() method, potentially overriding the default Order::STATE_PROCESSING.
D) It disables the initialize() method and sets the order state to Order::STATE_NEW.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Setting $_isInitializeNeeded to true in a payment method model is significant because it changes the behavior of the payment process. When this property is true, Magento will call the initialize() method of the payment method, passing a stateObject. This allows the payment method to set custom order state and status, potentially different from the default Order::STATE_PROCESSING. The initialize() method can set the state, status, and even control customer notification. If $_isInitializeNeeded is false or not set, Magento will use Order::STATE_PROCESSING as the default state and process the payment action directly. This question tests understanding of how Magento's payment processing can be customized and the impact of the $_isInitializeNeeded flag on order state determination.

\#\#\# Top Answer: If you want the index to be numbered, you can patch `\item` command to add numbering: First you need a new counter, so add

```
\newcounter{seqindexitem}
\renewcommand\theseqindexitem{\#\arabic{seqindexitem}}

```

to your preamble.
To change the `\item` command only for this one index, replace

```
\printindex[seq]

```

with

```
\begingroup
  \makeatletter
  \let\@@idxitem\@idxitem
  \renewcommand\@idxitem{%
    \@@idxitem
    \refstepcounter{seqindexitem}%
    \leavevmode\llap{\theseqindexitem:}
  }
  \printindex[seq]
\endgroup

```

By using `\refstepcounter` instead of `stepcounter` it becomes possible to add labels to the index entries to refer to the numbers.

The full code:

```
\documentclass{article}%                                                                      

\RequirePackage[para]{threeparttable}%
\RequirePackage{imakeidx}\makeindex%
\RequirePackage[unbalanced,indentunit=0.75em]{idxlayout}%

\RequirePackage{luacode}%

\newcounter{seqindexitem}
\renewcommand\theseqindexitem{\#\arabic{seqindexitem}}
\begin{luacode}
function Bsort(s)
--Patch the index to use Bridge sort order
    local t=""

    --Generate a sort key for the input sequence.
    for c in s:gmatch"." do
        if tonumber(c) ~= nil then
            t = t .. c
        end

        if c == "T" then
          t = t .. "A"
       end
        if c == "K" then
          t = t .. "B"
       end
        if c == "C" then
          t = t .. "C"
       end
        if c == "P" then
          t = t .. "D"
       end
        if c == "m" then
          t = t .. "E"
       end
        if c == "M" then
          t = t .. "F"
       end
        if c == "S" then
          t = t .. "G"
       end
    end

    --Section the index. 
    s = string.gsub(s, ";", "!;")

    --Prefix the index with the sort order.
    s = t .. "@" .. s

    -- Write the index back to LuaLaTeX.
    s = "\\index[seq]{" .. s .. "}"
    tex.sprint(s)
    return s
end
\end{luacode}

\DeclareRobustCommand{\Bsort}[1]{\directlua{Bsort("\luaescapestring{#1}")}}%
```

\#\#\# User: What's the strategy for computing the Picard group of a variety with more than one irreducible components? 

For instance, consider the simple case where $X$ has two components $C$ and $D$, meeting transversely at one point. Then it seems that $\\text{Pic}(X)\=\\text{Pic}(C)\\times\\text{Pic}(D),$ but I don't know how to prove it.

Thanks.

**Edit:** I'd like to see a formal proof (or a reference), i.e. using cohomology etc., instead of using "gluing", especially when we are not gluing along open intersections. The map $C\\coprod D\\to X$ is not flat, so there's no fppf gluing either.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I will only consider the case of connected projective (this is not really necessary) curves $X, C, D$. over an algebraically closed field $k$. The canonical injection $O\_X\\to O\_C\\times O\_D$ induces an exact sequence of sheaves on $X$ 
$$ 1 \\to O\_X^\* \\to O\_C^\* \\times O\_D^\* \\to F \\to 1 $$
where $F$ is a skyscrapper sheaf supported at the intersection points of $C$ and $D$. Passing to cohomology,
we get 
$$ 1 \\to k^\* \\to k^\* \\times k^\* \\to F(X) \\to \\mathrm{Pic}(X)\\to \\mathrm{Pic}(C) \\times \\mathrm{Pic}(D)\\to H^1(X, F)\=0\.$$ 
When $C, D$ intersect transversally at a single point (ordinary double point), a local computation shows that $k^\* \\times k^\*\\to F(X)$ is surjective, and you get your isomorphism. 

As Steven said, this really depends on how $C$ and $D$ intersect (in fact, when $C$ and $D$ are smooth, your isomorphism implies that $C$ and $D$ intersect transversally at a single point; non transversal intersection point can give additive subgroup in $\\mathrm{Pic}(X)$ and more transversally intersection points give subtori in $\\mathrm{Pic}(X)$). Also in higher dimension $H^1(X, F)$ may not vanish, and the above methode does not work. 

The general picture for proper curves can be found in Bosch, Lütkebohmert and Raynaud, Néron Models, Chap. 9\., §2\. They make a ''dévissage'' of $\\mathrm{Pic}^0(X)$. 

\[**EDIT**] Let me rewrite Sándor's nice interpretation in cohomological terms. It will make explicit the sheaf $F$ above and gives a better understanding of what is going on, and in any dimension. Denote by $E\=C\\cap D$ the closed subscheme defined by the ideal $J\_C\+J\_D$. Then we have an exact sequence of sheave on $X$: 
$$ 1 \\to O\_X^\* \\to O\_C^\* \\times O\_D^\* \\to O^\*\_{E} \\to 1 $$ 
in the middle, the map is $(a, b)\\mapsto a\|\_E (b\|\_E)^{\-1}$. The exactness is checked locally. Passing to cohomology, we get
$$ O(C)^\\star\\times O(D)^\\star\\to O(E)^\* \\to \\mathrm{Pic}(X) \\to \\mathrm{Pic}(C)\\times \\mathrm{Pic}(D)\\to \\mathrm{Pic}(E)$$
and the last map is $(L, H)\\mapsto L\_{\|E}\\otimes (H\_{\|E})^{\-1}$, therefore the exact sequence becomes

$$ O(C)^\\star\\times O(D)^\\star\\to O(E)^\\star \\to \\mathrm{Pic}(X) \\to \\mathrm{Pic}(C)\\times\_{\\mathrm{Pic}(E)} \\mathrm{Pic}(D)\\to 1\.$$
So Sándor's map $\\mathrm{Pic}(X) \\to \\mathrm{Pic}(C)\\times\_{\\mathrm{Pic}(E)} \\mathrm{Pic}(D)$ is always surjective. It is injective if and only if $O(C)^\\star\\times O(D)^\\star\\to O(E)^\\star$ is surjective. This is not always the case (consider two irreducible curves meeting at more than one point or meeting at a single point but not transversally which implies that $E$ is a non\-reduced point), but is true if for instance $O(E)\=k$ (e.g. $E$ is geometrically connected, geometrically reduced **and proper**). 

\[**EDIT 2**] Of course, in all this answer, $X$ is supposed to be **reduced**. Otherwise $O\_X\\to O\_C\\times O\_D$ (and that one with invertible functions) would not be necessarily injective. If $X$ is not reduced, there is a dévissage from $\\mathrm{Pic}(X)$ to $\\mathrm{Pic}(X\_{\\mathrm{red}})$ in Bosch \& al, *op. cit.*

10.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider a projective variety X over an algebraically closed field k, composed of two irreducible components C and D intersecting transversely at a single point. Which of the following statements about the Picard group of X is correct?

A) Pic(X) is always isomorphic to Pic(C) × Pic(D), regardless of how C and D intersect.

B) Pic(X) is isomorphic to Pic(C) × Pic(D) only when C and D intersect transversely at a single point.

C) Pic(X) is isomorphic to the fiber product Pic(C) ×Pic(E) Pic(D), where E is the intersection of C and D.

D) Pic(X) is always a subgroup of Pic(C) × Pic(D), with equality only in special cases.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The documentation provides a detailed analysis of the Picard group for varieties with multiple components. In the case where C and D intersect transversely at a single point, we have an isomorphism Pic(X) ≅ Pic(C) × Pic(D). This is because:

1) The exact sequence 1 → O_X^* → O_C^* × O_D^* → F → 1 leads to an isomorphism when C and D intersect transversely at a single point.

2) For more general intersections, Pic(X) may have a more complex structure, including possible additive subgroups or subtori.

3) The answer C is close but not precise enough, as the isomorphism to the fiber product holds in more general cases, not specifically for transverse intersection at a single point.

4) Answers A and D are incorrect as they don't accurately represent the relationship between Pic(X) and Pic(C) × Pic(D) in this specific case.

\#\#\# User: Let $\\mathcal{A}$ be an abelican category with enough injectives, let $K^\\bullet \\in Kom^\+(\\mathcal{A})$ be a complex, where $Kom^\+(\\mathcal{A})$ is the category of cochain complexes over $\\mathcal{A}$ bounded on the left. I read in Weibel's Homological algebra book that the Hyper(co)homology $\\mathbb{H}^n(K^\\bullet)$ of an exact complex $K^\\bullet$ is $0$ for all $n$, I also read somewhere else that the hyper(co)homology of an acyclic complex is $0$, but I didn't find a proof for both cases. 

Now let's say that I got a complex $K^\\bullet$ and that the cohomology of this complex $H^n(K^\\bullet) \= 0$ for $n \\geq m$, for some $m$. I want to know if this implies that $\\mathbb{H}^n(K^\\bullet) \= 0$ for $n \\geq m$? I couldn't find a reference for either case (exact and acyclic), can anybody help me?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Hypercohomology (with respect to any functor) of an exact\=acyclic complex is zero, because it is defined on the derived category and an exact complex is quasi\-isomorphic to the zero object.

The question in your last paragraph is only wishful thinking. If this were true, there would not be any cohomology theories. 

For an example to see that this fails take an arbitrary (say finite type over an algebraically closed field) scheme $X$ with a coherent sheaf $\\mathscr F$ that has nontrivial higher cohomology groups. (Say the sheaf $\\mathscr O(\-2\)$ on $\\mathbb P^1$). Then take $\\mathcal A$ to be the category of coherent sheaves on $X$, 
$K^\\bullet\=\\mathscr F$ (that is $K^0\=\\mathscr F$ and $K^i\=0$ for $i\\neq 0$) and consider the hypercohomology corresponding to the global section functor. By construction $h^n(K^\\bullet)\=0$ for $n\\neq 0$, but $\\mathbb H^n(K^\\bullet)\\neq 0$ for some $n\>0$. (In the case of 
$\\mathscr O(\-2\)$ on $\\mathbb P^1$, we have $\\mathbb H^1(K^\\bullet)\\neq 0$). 

Obviously there are many similar examples.

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider an abelian category A with enough injectives and a complex K• in Kom+(A), the category of cochain complexes over A bounded on the left. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the hypercohomology H^n(K•)?

A) If K• is exact, H^n(K•) = 0 for all n, but this may not be true if K• is only acyclic.
B) If the cohomology H^n(K•) = 0 for n ≥ m (some fixed m), then H^n(K•) = 0 for n ≥ m.
C) Hypercohomology of an acyclic complex is always 0, but this may not be true for exact complexes.
D) If K• is quasi-isomorphic to the zero object in the derived category, H^n(K•) = 0 for all n.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The correct answer is D. Hypercohomology is defined on the derived category, and an exact (or acyclic) complex is quasi-isomorphic to the zero object in the derived category. This implies that its hypercohomology vanishes.

Answer A is incorrect because hypercohomology vanishes for both exact and acyclic complexes.

Answer B is incorrect. The example given in the documentation disproves this: a coherent sheaf F on a scheme X can have H^n(K•) = 0 for n ≠ 0, but H^n(K•) ≠ 0 for some n > 0.

Answer C is incorrect because hypercohomology vanishes for both acyclic and exact complexes, not just acyclic ones.

This question tests understanding of hypercohomology, derived categories, and the relationship between exactness, acyclicity, and vanishing of hypercohomology.

\#\#\# User: I want to operate a small mixer in the freezer, for churning ice cream. I can close the door over the power cord, but the door seal isn't flexible enough to enclose the power cord, so it creates a crack. 

My idea is to make a small hole in the seal, for the power cord. If it is a tight fit, the cold loss during mixer operation will be minimal. But I don't plan to keep the mixer there permanently, so I'll have to seal the hole somehow. 

I think that an earplug will be the best seal. It is easily removed, and once inserted, it will expand to fit the hole perfectly. The foam should be a fairly good isolator. 

While it looks to me that this will work, it sounds slightly lunatic from some angles. Not being an experienced DIYer, and afraid to end up with a freezer which is constantly heated through a badly sealed hole, I want to ask you: Do you think this will work? Are there drawbacks I am missing? (Beside the freezer spending extra energy to cool a working motor, I think I can live with that). And are there better ways to do this? 

**update** in response to ppumpkin 

This is a standalone freezer, not a compartment in a fridge. It has no lightbulb or thermostat on the inside. 

The mixer will only be put in the freezer for ice cream making, so it won't be there most of the time. 

I have already thought of putting a socket in the freezer, caulking the hole for the power cord coming from outside. But while I can get wet\-room rated extensions, the cords of premade extensions are too thick to lead through the seal. So I'll have to make the extension myself, which is much less secure than connecting the mixer to a socket outside. 

The other idea was to build my own "mixer" from a 6 V DC motor and operate it from a li\-ion battery. But not only is it lots of work, li\-ion batteries at \-18°C aren't a good idea. So I still think that connecting the mixer outside is better. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Put the cord/hole in the top of the door, and it really won't matter:

The cold air is heavier than the air around it. So your freezer full of cold air is like a bucket of water: the cold air is trying to flow out only where gravity will let it. Other than the stirring of air causing the mingling of warm and cold air, a freezer doesn't need a top at all. Ever wondered how the open\-top freezers at the grocery store stay frozen? They're a big bucket, and the cold air is trapped by gravity.

So take advantage of that: Put your cord inlet at the top of your freezer, and don't worry about sealing it. The mixture/transfer of air at the cord inlet point will be negligible.

Option C is labor-intensive and impractical, especially since li-ion batteries don't perform well in extremely cold temperatures. Option D provides the best balance of effectiveness, simplicity, and safety.

\#\#\# User: How does Linux's Virtual Memory system handle the following case:

1. Process 1 maps one of its virtual page to physical frame 1\.
2. Context switches to process 2\.
3. Process 2 swaps out frame 1 and replace with its own content.
4. Context switches back to process 1\.

How does process 1 knows that it does not own the content of frame 1 and needs to do a swap in?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Technically, "process1" doesn't know this. There is a set of page\-tables for each process. The kernel knows which process it will switch to, and switch the page\-tables around. A part of these page\-tables is the kernel, which is shared between ALL processes (so, a certain part of the address range, typically in the range of 0xc0000000 to 0xffffffff \- although not ALL of those pages will be present). Typically, this shared section is achieved by simply making all the page\-table sets point at the same shared section of "kernel page\-table bits". 

Having this shared section allows the kernel calls, traps and interrupts to go into the kernel, no matter which process is currently running, or what that process is doing. 

Exactly how this works depends on the architecture the kernel is built for, but for example in x86(32 and 64 bit), CR3 is the register that points to the current page\-table. So for each process, there is a pointer to the page\-table, and it is loaded into CR3, as part of the switch to the new process, just like the register values (at least the stack\-pointer) is restored for the process 1 when it is being switched in.

13.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In a Linux system using virtual memory, what mechanism ensures that Process 1 correctly accesses its own memory after a context switch, even if another process has modified the physical frame?

A) Process 1 checks the frame content before each access
B) The CPU's CR3 register is updated to point to Process 1's page table
C) Process 1 maintains a separate copy of its memory content
D) The kernel notifies Process 1 of any changes to the physical frame

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B. In Linux's virtual memory system, each process has its own set of page tables. When a context switch occurs, the kernel updates the CPU's CR3 register to point to the page table of the process being switched to. This ensures that when Process 1 resumes execution, it uses its own page table, which maps its virtual addresses to the correct physical frames or indicates the need for a page fault if the data has been swapped out.

Option A is incorrect because processes don't check frame content before each access; this would be extremely inefficient.

Option C is incorrect as maintaining separate copies would defeat the purpose of virtual memory and be highly inefficient.

Option D is incorrect because the kernel doesn't directly notify processes about changes to physical frames. Instead, it manages this transparently through the page table mechanism.

This question tests understanding of virtual memory management, context switching, and the role of page tables and CPU registers in memory access.

\#\#\# User: I've been having a play and reading the [help](http://resources.arcgis.com/en/help/main/10.2/index.html#/What_are_reports_in_ArcGIS/004v00000001000000/) about a part of ArcMap I don't really use and that is the Reports. I thought I would teach myself a bit more about this by creating a simple report, for which I have spectacularly failed! 

I have a point dataset, say with 100 points and there is a text field that gives each point a type. For arguments sake I have types A, B, C and D.

I've been trying to create a single page that would give a count for each type, something that the [Summary Statistics tool](http://resources.arcgis.com/en/help/main/10.2/index.html#/Summary_Statistics/00080000001z000000/) can do. The end result would be a nice looking report with a simple table like:

```
Type  Count
A      25
B      25
C      30
D      20

```

That is it! Nothing more complex. Have I misunderstood what a report is actually about? I've tried setting Group Levels, Summary Function to count and Summary Group properties and have not succeeded in creating a simple table.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: It seems that it only provides this functionality if you group by a field, so you need at least 2 fields in your data. So in short, the answer is no. Not the way you want to do it. The main function of the reporting tools is to allow you to summarise data by groups.

Below I've tried to outline the process of creating the summary you want using a group.

I've created a single point feature class with 2 fields. One called "Type" as text. The other called "Number" as short field (this 2nd field could be whatever you want \- could even be blank).

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/uWxHP.jpg)

I will summarise this by the "Type" field.

* Start the Report Wizard (View \> Reports \> Create Report)
* Select both the "Type" and "Number" fields for the report and click "Next".
* Now create a group for the report based on the "Type" field. 
To do this double click on "Type" under "Report Fields:"

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/XlRDp.jpg)

* It should look like this.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/1rXe0.jpg)

* Keep clicking on "Next" and select your style, layout, orientation
etc... \-I've left everything as the default.
* On the last screen select to "Modify the report's design" and then
click "Finish".

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/maca0.jpg)

* The "Report Designer" will now open.
* From the left hand "Design Elements" menu, select the "Text Box" and
draw one anywhere on your report (you will move this later)
* Now that you've drawn a box, you can drag it into the header called
"gfType" on the report. This is the field that we grouped by.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/6dl10.jpg)

* It should look like this
![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/cOwCa.jpg)
* Now make sure this new text box is selected, you will see an "Element
Properties" window in the right hand side. Under "Data", set the
"Data Field" to "Type" \- This is the field we want to summarise by.
Now inder Under "Summary":
* Set the "Distinct Field" to "Type"
* Set the "Summary Function" to "Count"
* Set the "Summary group" to "ghType" (or whatever your group is called).
* Set the "Summary Running" to "Group"
* Set the "Summary Type" to "Sub Total"

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/L11Tz.jpg)

* Now click on the "Run Report" button (Top left)

You will see that the data has been grouped by "Type" and underneath each group there is a count of the total number of items in that group

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/yz2AU.jpg)

14.answer:

\#\#\# User: Since upgrading to *Ubuntu 12\.10* backups no longer work (using the default Deja\-Dup Backup tool). I always get the message: `No space left in ‘/’.` (which is **NOT** the path I backup to).

The preferences are set to back up my *Home* ignoring *Trash*. And the destination has \~500GB of space free!

Is there some way to get to the cause of this strange error? (which internally fails, because not being able to allocate space in */tmp*.)

EDIT:
Added more details.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **UPDATE** Please take a look below for go\-mtpfs example. go\-mtpfs is much more reliable, but the instructions remain very similar.

---

Automatically mounting Nexus 7
------------------------------

### Allow non\-root users to mount fuse devices:

`sudo vim /etc/fuse.conf`

```
Un-comment **user_allow_other**.

```

### Install mtpfs

`sudo apt-get install mtp-tools mtpfs`

### Make mount point

`sudo mkdir /mnt/nexus7`

`chown youruser:youruser /mnt/nexus7`

### Add udev rules

`sudo gedit /etc/udev/rules.d/99-android.rules`

```
#Nexus7 
SUBSYSTEM=="usb", SYSFS{idVendor}=="18d1", MODE="0666"

```

`sudo chmod +x /etc/udev/rules.d/99-android.rules`

### Add Nexus7 to fstab

`sudo vim /etc/fstab`

```
mtpfs /mnt/nexus7 fuse user,noauto,allow_other,defaults 0 0

```

### Restart udev

`sudo service udev restart`

### Access device

`mount /mnt/nexus7`

`umount /mnt/nexus7`

In summary we notice:

**Standard User**

* the userPrincipalName looks normal
* the login email can be found at: userPrincipalName
* creation type is: null

**Guest User**

* the userPrincipalName looks to be the external directories upn followed by '\#EXT\#' followed by this primary domain
* the login email can be found at: otherMails\[0]
* creation type is: null

**Local User**

* the userPrincipalName looks to be some object id followed by this primary domain
* the login email can be found at: signInNames\[0].value
* creation type is: LocalAccount

**Social User**

* the userPrincipalName looks to be 'cpim\_' followed by some object id followed by this primary domain
* the login email can be found at: otherMails\[0]
* creation type is: null

Although we can see some trends we'd rather not make guesses or bad assumptions. So we have the following questions:

1\) What is the best way to know which of the four types of user we're looking at?

2\) Is there a simpler way to get the login (ideally as one field, we're trying to build this into a simple mapping)? Other than :

```
If signInNames[0].value is not null use signInNames[0].value
Elseif otherMails[0] is not null use otherMails[0]
Else userPrincipalName

```

3\) Do other social users behave differently? (We've only done Facebook so far.)

4\) For social users what is the best way of knowing which identity provider is used?

**UPDATE 11/8:**

5\) Why don't LocalAccount users get an otherMail value?

6\) Why don't non\-LocalAccount users get sign\-in names? I guess that was added exclusively for B2C?

7\) Also I guess end users don't really have the ability to associate social and local accounts today? (unless using an app which leverages graph).

**UPDATE 11/8 \#2:**

8\) Is it safe (for now) to assume that I can disambiguate a B2C signed\-up individual who can only login with a social account using the following criteria:

* creation type is: null \- meaning they're not a Local User
* userPrincipalName is prefixed with 'cpim\_' followed by a UUID \- meaning they are PROBABLY not a Standard or Guest user

Or would there be a better method?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: 1\) These are not mutually exclusive properties. For example, a local account, guest or member user can also link their multiple social profiles to their account. The underlying data (available via Graph API) does not make any assumptions.

The most reliable way to know whether an account is a local user or not is to look at creationType property. You can also look at signInNames. Having said that, that would not imply that the user will not have their social profile linked in the future. It's just that this functionality is not exposed in B2C standard policies.

2\) `signInNames` is certainly used for signing in the user. However, a user can also have more than one `signInName` as far as the directory is concerned. That is why `signInNames` is a collection. So a utility company or bank may have an account id and email address both as `signInNames`.

`otherMails` is not a property used to sign in a user. So you may want to skip that. Think of `otherMails` as an email address that is not used for any critical function by the directory (e.g. it's not used for sign in or for password resets etc.)

You would use `userPrincipalName` for work accounts.

3\) All social accounts are considered as external user identities, and are mapped in the same way. They are not yet available through Graph API, but when they are, they will appear as a collection too since a user may link to multiple social accounts.

4\) Not possible today, but coming in the future.

**UPDATE 11/8** to answer additional questions

5\) Simply because there is no email address in B2C standard flow to add in `otherMails` for local account users. The email address they used to sign up is already in `signInNames` property. Through Graph API, you could add `otherMails`, and when a token is issued, it will show up in the `emails` claim even for local account users.

6\) Non\-local account users do not get a `signInName` because they do not need to sign in using a `signInNames`. Work accounts use the `userPrincipalName` instead which can be tied to Office 365, Exchange, or on\-premise AD. Social IDPs have external identities. So, there is no known scenario in which `signInNames` needs to be used for non\-local accounts at least today.

7\) Yes, it is not possible today to link a social account with a local account through standard policies, but can be done through custom policies. It is also not yet possible through Graph API (because external identities are not yet exposed), but will be possible in the future when the API is exposed.

**Update 11/24:**

8\) If you look at user principal name, you will notice it is random. cpim\_ can be removed any time, it is not part of the contract. In fact, IMHO, it should be removed already so apps do not take a dependency on it.

To determine this correctly, we are expecting to announce a new "userIdentities" property on the user account, using which you can determine which social IDPs is the user account linked to. That would be the best way to do this.

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the information provided:

Question: Which of the following statements is most accurate regarding user types and their identification in Azure AD B2C?

A) The creationType property is always set to "LocalAccount" for B2C users who signed up with email.

B) The userPrincipalName prefixed with 'cpim_' is a guaranteed method to identify social users.

C) The signInNames property is used exclusively for local account users and is never present for other user types.

D) User types are not mutually exclusive, and a local account user may have social profiles linked in the future.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because while creationType can be used to identify local accounts, it's not always set for every local account user.

Option B is incorrect because the 'cpim_' prefix in userPrincipalName is not a guaranteed or contractual way to identify social users and may be removed in the future.

Option C is incorrect because while signInNames is commonly used for local account users, it's not exclusive to them. Other user types could potentially have signInNames in certain scenarios.

Option D is correct because the documentation explicitly states that user types are not mutually exclusive. Local account users can have social profiles linked to their accounts in the future, especially if custom policies or future API developments allow for such linking.

```
java.lang.NoSuchMethodError: org.hibernate.type.CustomType.<init>
  (Lorg/hibernate/usertype/UserType;[Ljava/lang/String;)V ....

```

After looking around I got the impression that the PostGIS JDBC driver is not compatible with Hibernate, which would be strange. 

I'm using :

* hibernate\-spatial 1\.1\.1
* PostGIS JDBC 2\.0 (the link for 2\.1 is dead ...)
* postgresql\-8\.4\-702\.jdbc4
* Hibernate 3\.2\.5

The table I try to map is 

```
CREATE TABLE "cRef" (
    "id" SERIAL NOT NULL,
    "contenttype" varchar(200),
    "contentid" varchar(200) NOT NULL,
  PRIMARY KEY("id")
);
SELECT AddGeometryColumn ('cRef','geom',4326,'POINT',2);

```
```
<hibernate-configuration>
    <session-factory>
        <property name="hibernate.dialect">org.hibernatespatial.postgis.PostgisDialect
```

Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: A developer is setting up a Java application with Hibernate and PostGIS, but encounters a NoSuchMethodError. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this error, given the information provided?

A) The PostGIS JDBC driver is incompatible with the version of Hibernate being used
B) The hibernate-spatial and hibernate-spatial-postgis JAR files are missing from the classpath
C) The version of Hibernate (3.2.5) is too old and incompatible with hibernate-spatial 1.1.1
D) The PostgisDialect class is not properly configured in the hibernate.cfg.xml file

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A) While compatibility issues between PostGIS JDBC and Hibernate can occur, this specific error is more likely related to version mismatches between Hibernate core and Hibernate Spatial.
B) The classpath is explicitly stated to contain these JAR files, so this is not the issue.
C) This is the most likely cause. The NoSuchMethodError suggests that the method being called in the CustomType class doesn't exist in the version of Hibernate being used. Hibernate 3.2.5 is quite old, and Hibernate Spatial 1.1.1 may require a newer version of Hibernate core.
D) While the dialect configuration is important, an incorrect configuration would typically result in a different type of error, not a NoSuchMethodError.

The key to diagnosing this issue is recognizing that NoSuchMethodError often indicates a version mismatch between dependencies, and noting the old version of Hibernate being used compared to the more recent Hibernate Spatial library.

Question: A user reports that Safari is displaying scrambled text on certain websites, while other browsers like Chrome show the text correctly. What is the most likely cause of this issue and its potential solution?

A) The problem is caused by a virus, and running an antivirus scan should fix it.
B) It's a known bug related to fixed-width text display in Safari after a Lion upgrade, which can be resolved by following specific instructions.
C) The issue is due to outdated Safari version, and updating to the latest version will solve the problem.
D) The scrambled text is caused by incompatible fonts, and clearing the font cache will resolve the issue.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The documentation refers to a known bug in Safari, specifically mentioning "fixed-width text not appearing correctly in Safari after Lion upgrade." The top answer suggests that there are specific instructions available to fix this issue. This matches most closely with option B, which identifies it as a known bug related to fixed-width text display after a Lion upgrade and mentions that following specific instructions can resolve the problem.

Option A is incorrect because there's no indication that a virus is involved, and the issue is specific to Safari.
Option C is plausible but incorrect, as the problem is described as a bug rather than an outdated version issue.
Option D is also plausible but not supported by the given information, which doesn't mention font compatibility or cache issues.

\#\#\# User: In my house I have a mechanical water meter with a 2 wire reed switch that sends a pulse every 10 liters to (I suppose) an electronic meter to witch I don't have access. I'd like to connect a circuit to the same switch to read the pulses to track my water usage, without interfering with the electronic meter, but I don't know what circuit is already wired to the switch.
The only specs I've got on the sensor are " 24 Vca/Vcc, 0,1 A " and a simple diagram of a switch.

[![reed switch](https://i.stack.imgur.com/D6c1P.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/D6c1P.jpg)

I suppose, being a switch, that whatever circuit is currently connected, it must push a current through it when the switch closes to sense the switch closing. Maybe I could measure when current is flowing to sense the pulses? How could I do that without interfering with the electronic meter? Hall sensor? would that work? There's probably a simpler solution I'm not seeing.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Maybe add a hall sensor to the outside of the meter to sense the magnet that pulses the reed switch.

Or perhaps add a current sensor to the reed switch circuit, like a clip\-on hall sensor or current transformer.

20.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: An engineer wants to monitor water usage from a mechanical water meter with a reed switch, without interfering with the existing electronic meter. Which of the following solutions would be most appropriate and least intrusive?

A) Directly wire into the existing reed switch circuit in parallel
B) Replace the existing reed switch with a more advanced sensor
C) Install a Hall effect sensor near the existing reed switch
D) Add a pressure sensor to the water pipe

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: 
A) Directly wiring into the existing circuit could potentially interfere with the electronic meter's operation and may void warranties or violate regulations.

B) Replacing the existing reed switch would definitely interfere with the current setup and is unnecessarily invasive.

C) Installing a Hall effect sensor near the existing reed switch is the least intrusive method. It can detect the magnetic field changes without any physical connection to the existing circuitry, thus not interfering with the electronic meter.

D) Adding a pressure sensor to the water pipe is more invasive than necessary and may not provide accurate pulse readings like the reed switch does.

The Hall effect sensor solution aligns with the suggestion in the top answer and provides a non-contact method of detecting the pulses without risking interference with the existing system.

\#\#\# User: I've configured the Debian system on my netbook to shut down whenever the battery runs too low. Problem is, shutting down kills all running applications without giving them any chance to save any document I may be working on.

I'd like to write a script to "gently" close all open applications before shutdown kicks in, but I can't find a way to broadcast a "Close" message to all running applications in Gnome. Is there a way?

Thanks.

EDIT: Hibernating does not work on my netbook, so I can't use it as an alternative solution.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The shutdown will gently "close" (SIGTERM) all open applications, giving the opportunity to terminate gracefully. Then, after a time, if the process does not respond, a hard kill (SIGKILL) \- not giving time to *close* files or, more importantly, databases.

A shutdown is an autonomous procedure. It is not expected to respond to user input. So it would not allow for giving a user the option to save beforehand. This is the reason why both emacs and vi(m) have recovery files. Check with your applications if there is an auto\-save feature. For the most part, the old adage "Save early, save often" goes.

Have you thought to change the power settings to have the system [hibernate](http://wiki.debian.org/Hibernation)? This will save the state of the system (including running programs) for the next start.

21.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A system administrator is configuring a Debian netbook to handle low battery situations. Which of the following statements is true regarding the shutdown process and application behavior?

A) The shutdown process immediately terminates all applications without giving them a chance to save data.

B) Applications are first sent a SIGTERM signal, allowing for graceful termination, followed by a SIGKILL if they don't respond.

C) The shutdown process prompts users to save their work before closing applications.

D) Hibernation is always a viable alternative to shutdown for preserving application states.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
Option A is incorrect because the shutdown process does not immediately terminate all applications without giving them a chance to save data. It first attempts a graceful termination.

Option B is correct. The shutdown process first sends a SIGTERM signal to applications, allowing them to terminate gracefully and potentially save data. If an application doesn't respond within a certain timeframe, a SIGKILL signal is sent, which forcefully terminates the application.

Option C is incorrect because the shutdown process is autonomous and does not prompt users to save their work. It's the responsibility of applications to implement auto-save features or for users to save their work regularly.

Option D is incorrect because hibernation is not always a viable alternative. The question specifically mentions that hibernation does not work on this particular netbook, and therefore cannot be used as an alternative solution.

\#\#\# User: Today I went sightseeing in my city. After I got home I wrote the diary in English, but I didn't know what to call a place that sells "street food". Should I call it restaurant, cafe or something else?

**Street food:**  

![Street food](https://i.stack.imgur.com/1icFw.jpg)

**Update**  

From [Marcin's answer](https://english.stackexchange.com/a/51425/98), I searched each words in his/her answer to find out how to call each type of place that sells food.

**Food stall**
![Food stall](https://i.stack.imgur.com/ZNgSI.jpg)

**Food cart**
![Food cart](https://i.stack.imgur.com/kHPIi.jpg)

**Food van** (I'm not sure I can call it "Food van" or not, please correct me if I'm wrong)
![Food van](https://i.stack.imgur.com/A4XzH.jpg)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The answer depends on the physical nature of what the place is \- it might be a stall, a cart, a van, or something else. 

In the case of the sellers pictured, they are located at what appears to be a stall (a table on the street), or a cart (it looks like it has wheels).

Edit: In the US, a van that sells food is idiomatically referred to as a "food truck". You will no doubt be understood elsewhere if you use that expression, but in the UK, without the "food" qualifier, a "truck" and "van" are not the same thing.

22.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You're writing a travel blog about street food in different countries. Which of the following terms would be most appropriate to use when describing a mobile food service that operates out of a large vehicle, particularly in the United States?

A) Food stall
B) Food cart
C) Food truck
D) Food van

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct answer is C) Food truck. In the United States, a vehicle that sells food is idiomatically referred to as a "food truck". This term is widely understood and commonly used in American English.

A) Food stall is incorrect because it typically refers to a stationary setup, often a table or booth on the street, not a vehicle.

B) Food cart is incorrect because it usually describes a smaller, wheeled structure that can be pushed or pulled, not a large vehicle.

D) Food van, while potentially used in some regions, is not the standard term in the US. The documentation specifically mentions that in the UK, "van" and "truck" are not interchangeable, but "food truck" is the established term in American English.

This question tests the student's understanding of cultural and regional differences in terminology for mobile food services, as well as their ability to discern the most appropriate term for a specific context (in this case, the United States).

Question: Which of the following LaTeX code snippets correctly implements a customized box with a blue border, rounded corners, and specific text indentation according to the given specifications?

A) \newmdenv[innerlinewidth=0.5pt, roundcorner=4pt,linecolor=mycolor,innerleftmargin=6pt,
innerrightmargin=6pt,innertopmargin=6pt,innerbottommargin=6pt]{mybox}

B) \newmdenv[innerlinewidth=1pt, roundcorner=5pt,linecolor=mycolor,innerleftmargin=5pt,
innerrightmargin=5pt,innertopmargin=5pt,innerbottommargin=5pt]{mybox}

C) \newmdenv[outerlinewidth=0.5pt, roundcorner=4pt,linecolor=mycolor,outerleftmargin=6pt,
outerrightmargin=6pt,outertopmargin=6pt,outerbottommargin=6pt]{mybox}

D) \newmdenv[innerlinewidth=0.5pt, roundcorner=4pt,linecolor=blue,innerleftmargin=6pt,
innerrightmargin=6pt,innertopmargin=6pt,innerbottommargin=6pt]{mybox}

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: Option A is the correct implementation because:
1. It uses innerlinewidth=0.5pt, which matches the specified thick line of 0.5pt.
2. The roundcorner=4pt matches the required radius of 4pt for the corners.
3. It uses linecolor=mycolor, which refers to the custom color defined earlier.
4. All inner margins (left, right, top, bottom) are set to 6pt, matching the required text indentation on all sides.

Option B is incorrect because it uses different values for line width (1pt instead of 0.5pt) and corner radius (5pt instead of 4pt), and the margins are set to 5pt instead of 6pt.

Option C is incorrect because it uses outer margins instead of inner margins, which would affect the box size rather than the text indentation. It also uses outerlinewidth instead of innerlinewidth.

Option D is almost correct, but it uses linecolor=blue instead of linecolor=mycolor, which would not use the custom color defined in the specifications.

\#\#\# User: Which one is better and correct answer for below question?
Can we use May have for current possibilities?

Que : Where is your boss ?

Ans 1 : He may have left for the day.

Ans 2 : He may be left for the day. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: **May have** \+ past participle refers to something that happened in the past: **may be** refers to something that is happening now.

> He may have left for the day \- *past*   
> 
>  He may be in his office \- *present*

Note that **[maybe](https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/maybe)** (without the space) can be used to intruduce doubt into a sentence. It as an adverb, so it can be used in three positions:

> He went out for lunch  
> 
>  Maye he went out for lunch  
> 
>  He maybe went out for lunch.  
> 
>  He went out for lunch, maybe.

**left for the day** has a lasting effect, so you can't just use simple past: you have to use present perfect 

> Maybe he has left for the day

24.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following sentences correctly expresses a current possibility about the boss's whereabouts?

A) The boss may have been leaving for the day.
B) The boss may be left for the day.
C) The boss may be leaving for the day.
D) The boss maybe left for the day.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:

A) Incorrect. "May have been leaving" suggests a past continuous action that was possible, not a current possibility.

B) Incorrect. "May be left" is grammatically incorrect. "Left" is not used in passive voice in this context.

C) Correct. "May be leaving" uses the present continuous tense with "may" to express a current possibility. This correctly indicates that the boss might be in the process of leaving right now.

D) Incorrect. "Maybe left" uses "maybe" as an adverb, which doesn't properly express the intended meaning of possibility. Additionally, the simple past tense "left" doesn't convey a current situation.

This question tests understanding of modal verbs, tense usage, and the difference between "may be" and "maybe" in expressing current possibilities.

This happens only when I use a remote connection. If I am connected to the LAN and connect to the Exchange server using the FQDN, I am able to use all those resources without problem. I have already tested from my smartphone and both mail and web are working fine.

\<**updated**\>This website is online from a web test that I have made. I can access through 4G in my smartphone.\<**updated**\>

I really cannot understand what is happening.

**Network specs:**

* Chrome

**UPDATE:**

**UPDATE 2:**

There is a NAT rule to forward from public port 443 to private server x at port 443\. There is no ACLs and proxys config in this router.

I forgot to say that this uplink to this company (from the carrier is a fiber) is in a subnet (255\.255\.255\.252\) with a dedicated IP where there is also in the subnet, the subnet ID, gateway and broadcast. I think that maybe there is a proxy in the gateway of my ISP.

I have also another FQDN in dyndns running and inside of this private network it leads to my router config page, and with /owa to that page where nginx is running. From outside this link leads to the right website. 

**UPDATE 5:**

Since this problem is being a struggle, I will resume it. 

I have two FQDNs pointed to a static IP, who is being used in the WAN port. One is set in a remote server, the remote.x.pt (FQDN1\), the other is set by dyndns, x.dyndns.biz(FQDN2\).

In my pfsense I have a NAT rule to forward traffic to a internal server from port 443 to port 443\.

I am blocking traffic each network in my pfsense router, who are two networks.

\#\#\# Top Answer: The Draytek routers will often use port 443 for their own purposes \- either SSL VPN and/or remote management. Go in to the router config, check the ports being used. Even if you aren't using the SSL VPN, change the port (4433 for example). 25.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided StackExchange documentation:

Question: A company is experiencing issues with remote access to their Exchange server. Users can access the server from within the LAN, but not from outside networks. The network uses a Draytek 2830 router with NAT rules to forward traffic to the Exchange server. What is the most likely cause of this issue and the recommended solution?

A) The Exchange server's firewall is blocking external connections. Disable the firewall on the Exchange server.

B) The NAT rule is incorrectly configured. Review and update the port forwarding settings in the router.

C) The Draytek router is using port 443 for its own purposes, conflicting with the Exchange server. Change the router's SSL VPN and management ports.

D) The ISP is blocking access to the Exchange server. Contact the ISP to allow traffic to the server's public IP address.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The most likely cause of this issue is that the Draytek router is using port 443 for its own purposes, such as SSL VPN or remote management. This conflicts with the Exchange server, which typically uses port 443 for secure connections. The recommended solution is to change the router's SSL VPN and management ports to different values (e.g., 4433) and ensure that remote management from the internet is disabled. This will free up port 443 for the Exchange server traffic and resolve the remote access issues.

Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Which of the following best explains the meaning and usage of the phrase "happen to know" in the sentence "Do you happen to know if she has a boyfriend?"

A) It indicates that the speaker is certain about the information being requested.
B) It suggests that the speaker is making a formal inquiry about someone's relationship status.
C) It implies that the speaker is asking if the listener knows by chance or coincidentally.
D) It means the speaker is demanding that the listener must know this information.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The phrase "happen to know" is an idiomatic expression that means "to know by chance" or "to coincidentally have knowledge about something." In this context, it's used to ask a question in a casual, non-intrusive way. The speaker is not assuming that the listener definitely has this information, but is rather inquiring if they might have come across this knowledge incidentally. Options A, B, and D all misinterpret the tone and implication of the phrase, either by suggesting certainty, formality, or demand, which are not accurate representations of how "happen to know" is used in everyday language.

\#\#\# User: *I have never been to China*. **Have you been there.**

I am wondering the reason why there has not used the preposition " to" after been at the bold part, although such a preposition has been used at the italic part!

Any help would be appreciated

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I have never been to China. Have you been there? Why there is not "to" after been.

First off. the words "here/there" are adverbs and you don't use the preposition "to" before these adverbs. 

Second, the preposition "to" is inherent in the meaning of these adverbs. They mean "to, at, or in this/that place". So we don't need to use the preposition "to" before "there" or "here" in the same way as we don't use "to" before home when it's used as an adverb to mean "to the place we live". 

I think it'll not be out of place if I mention that, although here/there means to/at/in this/that place, we use in/over before these adverbs such as it's hot in here, put it over there, etc. in conversation.

27.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which statement best explains the grammatical difference between "I have never been to China" and "Have you been there"?

A) "To" is omitted in the second sentence because it's a question.
B) "There" inherently includes the meaning of "to that place," making "to" redundant.
C) "Been" changes its meaning in questions and doesn't require "to."
D) "To" is only used with specific country names, not with "there."

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The correct answer is B. The adverb "there" inherently includes the meaning of "to that place," making the preposition "to" redundant. This is why we say "Have you been there?" instead of "Have you been to there?" The word "there" functions as an adverb of place, encompassing the idea of direction or location without needing an additional preposition.

Option A is incorrect because the question form doesn't determine the use of "to."
Option C is wrong because "been" retains its meaning in both statements and questions.
Option D is incorrect as "to" can be used with various place names, not just countries.

This question tests understanding of adverbs of place, prepositions, and subtle differences in English sentence structure.

\#\#\# User: Although I understand the derivation of boundary condition in case of steady electric current but I did not understand, that the electric field which is in direction of $J$ current density that is applied between two conducting medium so that if we analyse this electric field we should get that both tangent and normal component bet two medium is the same not only tangent component and the value of $J$ change due to different value of conductivity bet medium while the direction should still the same.

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/QAlyw.png)

ok my question what if the field like i draw why the direction of current change although the same source should make the current,electric field in both conductors in the same direction ![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/D6YhS.png)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I'm not exactly clear what your question is. Your two equations have two distinct sources:

* The normal components must be equal, $J\_{1n}\=J\_{2n}$, because otherwise there would be an accumulation of charge into the surface, which cannot be sustained in the steady state. This is because, for a normal from 1 into 2, the flow of charge that exits medium 1 in a small area $dA$ is $J\_{1n}dA$ and the charge entering medium 2 is $J\_{2n}dA$.
* The tangential components on the other hand, can be different, because charge is just flowing past the boundary at different speeds. On the other hand, the electric field's tangential components must be continuous across the boundary, because otherwise there would be a nonzero circulation in the loop in your image. In a metal where Ohm's law holds, the current density is proportional to electric field,
$$\\mathbf{J}\=\\sigma \\mathbf{E}$$
and therefore the current density's tangential components will not in general be constant across the boundary.

This actually makes a lot of sense physically. Consider the following situation: two conductors of (smallish) conductivities $\\sigma\_1$ and $\\sigma\_2$ are "sandwiched" between conducting plates with an applied voltage:

![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/wSAJu.png)

Here you'd expect the current to be vertical, and greater in the material with greater conductivity. Thus the current density components tangential to the separating surface will *not* be equal.

28.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Consider two conducting media with different conductivities σ₁ and σ₂, placed between two conducting plates with an applied voltage. At the boundary between the two media, which of the following statements is correct regarding the electric field E and current density J?

A) Both the normal and tangential components of E and J are continuous across the boundary.

B) The normal component of J and the tangential component of E are continuous across the boundary, while the tangential component of J may be discontinuous.

C) The normal component of E and the tangential component of J are continuous across the boundary, while the normal component of J may be discontinuous.

D) Both the normal and tangential components of E and J are discontinuous across the boundary.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: 
The correct answer is B because:
1. The normal component of J must be continuous (J₁ₙ = J₂ₙ) to prevent charge accumulation at the boundary in steady state.
2. The tangential component of E must be continuous to avoid infinite circulation of the electric field.
3. The tangential component of J can be discontinuous due to different conductivities (σ₁ ≠ σ₂) and Ohm's law (J = σE).
4. The normal component of E can be discontinuous due to different conductivities.

Option A is incorrect because the tangential component of J can be discontinuous. 
Option C is incorrect because it's the normal component of J, not E, that must be continuous.
Option D is incorrect because both E and J have continuous components across the boundary.

\#\#\# User: Jabref\-4\.1 is still not as stable as Jabref\-3\.8 was. Jabref stores some metadata such as groups in comments of the Bibtex database.

Jabref\-4\.x changed the file format unfortunately. I am not sure, if it was just the format how groups are saved.

How to convert a .bib database on a Linux system from the Jabref\-4\.x format back to the old format used in the final version 3\.8\.2?

Is there any feature which will get lost, because it was not known in the old file format?

Update: Thank you for the helpful comments so far. I upvoted several already. I will review now within the next days, perhaps my question is invalid or needs improvement.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: My bib file in v3\.8\.2 is just slightly different from that in v4\.1\. The only difference is in `@Comment{jabref-meta`

To downgrade the bib file into the format compatible with v3\.8\.2, only 3 replacements need to be done. They are:

1. `grouping` \-\> `groupstree`
2. `StaticGroup` \-\> `ExplicitGroup`
3. remove all occurrences of `\;1\;\;\;`

---

FYI, in my v3\.8\.2 bib file, the group information is associated with entries\-\-\-the `groups` field of an entry records the associated group(s) (separated by comma). The group comment just stores the hierarchical structure.

e.g.

```
@Article{LEcuyer-2007a,
  author     = {L'Ecuyer, Pierre and Simard, Richard},
  title      = {TestU01: A C Library for Empirical Testing of Random Number Generators},
  journal    = {ACM Trans. Math. Softw.},
  year       = {2007},
  volume     = {33},
  number     = {4},
  pages      = {22:1--22:40},
  month      = aug,
  doi        = {10.1145/1268776.1268777},
  groups     = {PRNG},
  numpages   = {40},
  publisher  = {ACM},
}

```

30.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: When converting a JabRef 4.x .bib file to the older 3.8.2 format, which of the following changes is NOT necessary?

A) Replacing 'grouping' with 'groupstree' in the @Comment{jabref-meta} section
B) Changing 'StaticGroup' to 'ExplicitGroup'
C) Removing all occurrences of '\;1\;\;'
D) Modifying the 'groups' field in individual entries

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The question tests understanding of the differences between JabRef 4.x and 3.8.2 .bib file formats. Options A, B, and C are all necessary changes mentioned in the documentation for downgrading from 4.x to 3.8.2 format. However, option D is not mentioned as a required change. The 'groups' field in individual entries is present in both versions and does not need modification. The information states that the group information is associated with entries in the same way in both versions, with the 'groups' field recording the associated group(s) separated by commas. Therefore, D is the correct answer as it is not a necessary change when converting between these versions.
